questions.text: A 40-year old female underwent total thyroidectomy for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. On the third postoperative day, the patient complains of numbness in her fingers and perioral area. Her serum calcium level is 6 mg/dl. Which of the following vessels would have been injured during the surgery, resulting in this clinical scenario?

choices.text: Anterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Posterior branch of superior thyroid artery
Superior branch of inferior thyroid artery
Inferior branch of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoparathyroidism. Parathyroid glands are supplied by the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery. Injury to this vessel during surgery would result in postoperative hypoparathyroidism.

The parathyroid glands are small yellowish-brown structures lying between the posterior border of the thyroid gland and its capsule.

They are supplied by the superior branch of the inferior thyroid artery. They secrete parathormone which helps in the regulation of the serum calcium.

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student received booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination, following which she developed weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. The lesion is most likely to be in which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve also called a Surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

Named nerves of the upper limb:

  • Laborer’s nerve: Median nerve.
  • Musician’s nerve: Ulnar nerve.
  • Surgeon’s nerve: Axillary nerve.
  • Nerve of Bell: Long thoracic nerve.

Course of Axillary nerve:

  • Origin -  Posterior cord of brachial plexus in the axilla. 
  • In Axilla - Exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm.
  • In Arm - Winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of deltoid "upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm".

Axillary nerve Injury: 

Injury mostly is due to fracture of surgical neck of humerus, inferior dislocation of humerus and inadvertent IM injection.

Test: Loss of sensation over the skin of the lower part of the deltoid muscle (regimental badge anesthesia) in case of lesion of the nerve.

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. However, he accidentally advanced the needle causing injury to the structure lying immediately medial to the femoral vein, lying within the femoral sheath. Which of the following structures is injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and lymph node of Cloquet. 

Presence of this canal allows femoral vein to extend.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle.

questions.text: Area marked "?" in the diagram below is ________.
questions.solution:
The image is of the floor of the 4th ventricle, and the area marked "?" is the hypoglossal triangle.

The floor of the 4th ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of medulla. It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area. The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area. At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea. At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus. Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of vagus.

questions.text: A thyroid mass usually moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia:

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
A thyroid mass usually moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. The posteromedial aspects of the thyroid lobes are attached to the side of the cricoid cartilage by Berry’s ligament which is formed by the condensation of pretracheal fascia. It is responsible for the movement of thyroid mass with swallowing.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

  • The pretracheal layer which encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either sides forms suspensory ligament which is known as ligament of Berry.
  • The carotid sheath which is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses the common and internal carotid arteries, internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

As Mupirocin has no structural similarities with existing systemic antibiotics that might lead to the development of cross-resistance and has minimal toxicity in its topical form, it is approved for the prevention of MRSA outbreaks.

Mixed therapy with systemic agents is not preferred as it would cause unnecessary antibiotic exposure potentially paving way for drug resistance. 

Mupirocin is a unique antimicrobial agent because of its structure and mechanism of action. Mupirocin exerts its antimicrobial activity by reversibly inhibiting isoleucyl-transfer RNA, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein and RNA synthesis.

Oral antibiotics should be considered only in conjunction with topical agents and when all other decolonization attempts and environmental controls have been exhausted.

questions.text: A child presents at 6 weeks of age for vaccination and the clinician decides to give a combination vaccine of Diphtheria, Pertussis, and tetanus toxoid. How does this affect the body's immune response  against tetanus toxoid  compared to if it was given alone?

choices.text: Remains same whether given alone or in combination as DTP
Decreases as the immune system is divided to make antibodies against 3 antigens instead of one
Increases as multiple antigens increases the immune response

questions.solution:
The immune response against the tetanus toxoid increases if given as a combination of DTP when compared to given singly.

Since this vaccine is given first time, response to tetanus toxoid would be enhanced. If it was given in an older child with history of other vaccinations, immune response would differ.

The immune response is variable in response to multiple antigens depending on the antigenic competition.

  • If 2 bacterial vaccines(say cholera and typhoid) are given, antibodies are produced as if they are given separately.
  • If 2 toxoids(say tetanus and diphtheria) are given with one in excess, the antibody response to the other is diminished
  • If a toxoid is given with a bacterial vaccine(say DTP vaccine), the antibody response to the toxoid is potentiated
  • If a toxoid is administered earlier, and then given along with a bacterial vaccine, the antibody response to the bacterial vaccine is diminished.

Other factors may also play a role in antibody response including

Size and number of doses - a minimum critical dose is required, to elicit response against an antigen. It increases with an increase in dose, upto a certain point, after which it rather induces tolerance.

Route of administration- parenteral route induces better antibody response compared to oral or nasal route.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine.

The botulinum toxins produced by Clostridium botulinum are neurotoxins that cleave the SNARE (soluble NSF attachment protein receptor) family of proteins involved in vesicular fusion and subsequently neurotransmitter release. Preformed toxins when ingested can cause food-borne botulism. The botulinum toxins block the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cause flaccid paralysis. Symptoms can include ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

Eight different serotypes of toxin have been identified which are produced by Clostridium botulinum. All of them are neurotoxins except C2. The various SNARE proteins cleaved are:

  • Synaptobrevin- cleaved by serotypes B, D, F, & G
  • SNAP-25 - cleaved by serotypes A & E
  • Syntoxin - cleaved by serotype C1

The image given below shows the site of action of botulinum toxin.

Infant botulism is also called floppy baby syndrome. It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months. It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxins. Affected children usually present with paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weakness, altered crying, and loss of head control.

Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxins or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

The image given below shows gram staining of Clostridium botulinum.

Other Options:

Option B: Inhibits acetylcholine esterase: Organophosphates, carbamates, and certain nerve agents like sarin prevent acetylcholine breakdown by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

Option C: Inhibits reuptake of acetylcholine: Hemicholinium blocks the reuptake of choline, preventing acetylcholine synthesis.

Option D: Blockage of postsynaptic receptors of acetylcholine: α-bungarotoxin, curare, and α-conotoxin act as competitive antagonists at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely organism that is inoculated on the medium given below ?
questions.solution:
The culture medium depicted in the given image is the Castenada biphasic medium, which is used to isolate the Brucella species.

Brucella are small, non-motile, aerobic, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B.melitensis, B. suis, and B.abortus.

Brucellosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs, and other animals.

Once the infection is transmitted, these bacteria resist intracellular digestion and proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system for a long time. This is the reason why brucellosis often becomes chronic and is resistant to simple antimicrobial therapy. The host immune response is mainly cell-mediated involving activated macrophages, helper T-cells, and mediators such as TNF alpha, TNF gamma, IL-1, and IL-12. 

Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever, as in this patient, characterized by a rising and falling fever. They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis is important and includes several methods such as- 

  • Polymerase chain reaction is a sensitive and reliable method of detection. 
  • Culture of Brucella species can be done from specimen including blood, bone marrow aspirate, lymph node aspirate, CSF, and urine. Preferred method and medium of culture includes theCastaneda method. It is a biphasic medium. The solid component is the agar slant and the liquid is the broth. The medium is inoculated with the specimen and incubated for four days in an upright position. Serial subcultures can be obtained by slanting the broth over the agar periodically to inoculate new colonies. 
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test,Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Cut-offs for significant titers are variable depending on the endemicity. Endemic areas or history of laboratory exposure require agglutinin titers of 1:320–1:640 or higher and in nonendemic areas, a titer of more than or equal to 1:160 is considered diagnostic.
  • Tests for animals and animal products include tests such as the milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.
    • Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed well with hematoxylin stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies to brucella antigens, agglutination occurs with the agglutinate rising to the top as a blue ring. If the sample does not contain antibodies to brucella antigens, the whole of the sample is uniformly stained blue. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with at least two agents for six weeks duration. The preferred combination is IM streptomycin 0.75-1g per day for two to three weeks along with doxycycline 100mg BD for six weeks. 

Prevention of Brucellosis is important by screening and abiding by safety standards in farms and dairy industries, and also by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The Intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects typical to metoclopramide. The most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.

Restlessness, drowsiness, insomnia, anxiety, and agitation occur in 10–20% of patients, especially the elderly.

Extrapyramidal effects (dystonias, akathisia, parkinsonian features) due to central dopamine receptor blockade occur acutely in 25% of patients given high doses and in 5% of patients receiving long-term therapy. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Hence, long-term use should be avoided unless absolutely necessary, especially in the elderly.

  • Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, using multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg since the last 7 days. The patient gives the history of similar episodes over the past 8 years which resolve spontaneously after 7-10 days. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

questions.text: Correct pairing of drug and its mechanism of action among the following is?
questions.solution:
Rituximab is an anti CD20 monoclonal antibody.

  • Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 B-cell antigen. CD20 is found on cells from the pre–B cell stage through its terminal differentiation to plasma cells and is expressed on 90% of B-cell neoplasms.
  • Monoclonal antibody binding to CD20 generates transmembrane signals that produce autophosphorylation and activation of serine/tyrosine protein kinases, induction of c-Myc oncogene expression, and expression of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules.
  • Rituximab is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma(DLBCL).
  • It remains effective in patients who relapse after initial treatment with rituximab-based combinations.
  • Rituximab improves response rates when added to combination chemotherapy for other indolent B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (NHLs), including CLL, mantle cell lymphoma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia, and marginal zone lymphomas.

The EGFR belongs to the ErbB family of transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinases also known as ErbB1 or HER1 (human EGFR 1). EGFR is essential for the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells.

Two separate classes of drugs that target the EGFR pathway are important in the therapy of solid tumors:

Monoclonal antibodies recognize the extracellular domain of the EGFR, inhibit ligand-induced signaling, and can elicit an immune response. Cetuximab is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signaling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma(HNSCC).
  2. Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind to the intracellular kinase domain and inhibit the enzymatic function of an EGFR. Erlotinib is a reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for advanced non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) with mutant EGFR and advanced pancreatic cancer in combination with gemcitabine.

Trastuzumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody of HER2-human epidermal growth factor receptor 2, inhibiting hetero- and homodimerization and signal transduction. It is approved for HER2-overexpressing breast and gastric cancer.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon applied a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness in his toes but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, the patient informs the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said that he was busy. After a few days the patient developed permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  1. The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  2. The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  3. When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min, blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis, Hypocalcemia,  Blood Urea – 100 mg/dl, Creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of Sodium bicarbonate, Calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
He most likely consumed Ethylene glycol. 

This patient with h/o consumption of a substance, presented with acute onset CNS depression (drowsiness), Tachycardia (130/min) and Tachypnoea (30/min). On preliminary lab analysis he was found to have severe Metabolic acidosis, Acute Kidney Injury (Elevated BUN & Creatinine) with Hypocalcemia - most likely due to precipitation of Calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

This patients condition improved when was promptly treated with Nasogastric lavage & aspiration (to remove residual substance), Sodium bicarbonate (to counter falling pH from severe metabolic acidosis), Calcium gluconate (Hypocalcemia) and 4-methylpyrazole - Fomipezole (Alcohol Dehydrogenase inhibitor).

All these features, particularly including the presence of Kidney damage (AKI) points towards Ethylene glycol poisoning.

Methyl alcohol (Methanol) and Ethylene glycol poisoning can present very similarly. However, the key distinguishing feature of Methanol poisoning is the presence of eye symptoms (as opposed to kidney damage in ethylene glycol) - like blurring of vision/loss of vision due to retinal damage by formate metabolites.

Methanol--Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ADH) ⇒ Formaldehyde (Retinal damage)

Ethylene glycol--Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ADH) ⇒ Glyoxyaldehyde ⇒ (Kidney damage) 

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same and predominantly involves using Fomipezole or Ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A patient suffering from orofacial paresthesia, tremor and ataxia has been diagnosed with intoxication from a poison associated with chronic consumption of certain fish. Which of the following explains the mechanism of this poison?

choices.text: Binding to sulfhydryl groups on enzymes

questions.solution:
The patient in this question is suffering from chronic organic mercury poisoning (methyl mercury), most commonly associated with consumption of mercury-rich fish (such as shark, swordfish, bonito, mackerel, marlin and bluefin tuna).   • Both inorganic and methylmercury damage mitochondria and disrupt intracellular calcium homeostasis.
  • Methylmercury also affects the MAPK signaling pathway.
  • Methylmercury has also been shown to disrupt microtubules in neurites.

  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female had to undergo a cesarean section in an institution due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).
  • In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive full incentive after completing the remaining visits.
  • ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.
  • If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.
  • In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with: BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until 42nd day.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements.

questions.text: Community X has 30% population  who are below 15 years of age and 10% population over 65 years. The dependency ratio here would be:
questions.solution:
Total dependency ratio = 100* (Total population below 15 years and above 65 years)/(Total population in the age group of 15 – 64).

Here 30% of the population is less than 15 years and 10% is greater than 65 years. Hence the percentage of population between age 15-64 years=100-(30+40)= 60%.

Hence, the dependency ratio would be 100* (30% + 10%)/60% = 66.6%.

Dependency ratio:

  • Persons 65 years and above and children from 0 – 14 years are considered as dependents.
  • The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 – 65 years.
  • Total dependency ratio = (children 0-14 years age + population above 65 years age) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64).
  • It is also called societal dependency ratio.
  • The total dependency ratio can also be divided into young age dependency ratio and old age dependency ratio
  • As of 2016, the dependency ratio of India is 52%.
  • Potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old age dependency ratio.

questions.text: What is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
Perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Crude death rate = ( Number of deaths during the year/Mid year population ) x 1000

Age specific death rate = ( Number of deaths in specific age groups/Mid year population of that age group ) x 1000

Sex specific death rate = ( Number of deaths per year of that sex/Mid year population of that sex ) x 1000

Case fatality rate = ( Total number of deaths due to a particular disease/Total number of cases due to same disease ) x 100

Proportional mortality from a particular disease = ( Number of deaths from a specific disease in a year/ Total deaths from all causes in a year ) x 100

Under 5 mortality rate = ( Number of deaths under 5 yrs of age in a year/Total live birth in that year ) x 1000

Survival rate = ( Total number of patients alive after 5 yrs /Total number of patients diagnosed or treated ) x 100

questions.text: The strength of domestic sewage is being measured in a particular area. What is the minimum amount of suspended solids that should be there to consider the sewage as 'strong'?
questions.solution:
The strength of sewage is considered as strong if the amount of suspended solids is 500mg/L. If the amount is 100mg/L, then the sewage is considered as weak.

The strength of sewage is expressed in terms of biochemical oxygen demand, chemical oxygen demand, and suspended solids.

Related Pearl: Strength of Sewage

The strength of sewage is expressed by the following.

  • Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)
    • It is the most important test done on sewage
    • It is the standard test which is an indicator of organic content of sewage
    • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20 deg.C) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
    • A high BOD (300 mg/l) indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD (100mg/l) indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
  • Chemical oxygen demand (COD)
    • This test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample which is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer.
    • This is mostly used when sewage contains toxic wastes
  • Suspended solids
    • The amount of suspended solids in sewage may vary from 100 to 500 ppm (mg/litre)
    • If the level of suspended solids is 100 ppm, then sewage is weak and if it is more than 500 ppm, sewage is strong.

questions.text: Malaria is an example of _____ type of biological transmission in vector-borne diseases.
questions.solution:
• Malaria is an example of cyclo-propagative transmission.
  • In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in mosquitoes.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of a keto diet for weight loss. Weight of the participants was measured before starting the keto diet and after 1 month of the keto diet.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to test the statistical significance of the change in weight?
questions.solution:
Since the effect of keto diet is checked on the same individuals, before and after the keto diet, therefore the test used is paired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age specific mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate can change with changes in age specific mortality rates. General fertility rate, total fertility rate, and gross reproduction rate are not dependent on age specific mortality rate.

Net Reproduction Rate: It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

  • Crude birth rate
    • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory.
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year.
    • Birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/Estimated mid-year population
    • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population
  • General Fertility Rate
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15 - 49 years) in a given year.
    • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age in the same area in the same year.
    • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
    • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth
  • Age-specific fertility rates
    • It is the number of live births in a year to 1000 women in any specified age group.
    • It is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.
    • ASFR = Number of live births in a particular age group x 1000/Mid-year female population of the same age group.
  • Total Fertility Rate
    • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
    • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
    • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.
  • Gross Reproductive Rate
    • It is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.
  • Net Reproduction Rate
    • It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
    • NRR is a demographic indicator.
    • NRR of 1 is equivalent of approximately the 2 child norm.
    • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate.

questions.text: The prothrombin time (PT) assay does not assess the function of:
questions.solution:
The prothrombin time (PT) assay does not assess the function of Factor VIII.

The prothrombin time (PT) assay assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway:

factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

Factor VIII is a protein involved in intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

PT assay- Tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to plasma and the time for a fibrin clot to form is recorded.

A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. questions.text: Which of the following  is not true about autophagy?

choices.text: Microautophagy is the major form of autophagy
LC3  is a useful marker for autophagy

questions.solution:
Microautophagy is not the major form of autophagy. Macroautophagy is the major form.

Autophagy is a process in which a cell eats its own contents.

It involves the delivery of cytoplasmic materials to the lysosome for degradation. Depending on how the material is delivered, autophagy can be categorized into three types:

  • Chaperone-mediated autophagy- direct translocation across the lysosomal membrane by chaperone proteins
  • Microautophagy- inward invagination of lysosomal membrane for delivery
  • Macroautophagy- the major form of autophagy involving the sequestration and transportation of portions of cytosol in a double membrane-bound autophagic vacuole (autophagosome)

Other options:

The synthesis of LC3 (microtubule-associated protein light chain 3) is augmented during autophagy and it is therefore a useful marker for autophagy.

Autophagy functions as a survival mechanism under various stress conditions, it is therefore prominent in atrophic cells.

Role of autophagy in human diseases:

  • Cancer:  autophagy can both promote cancer growth and act as a defense against cancers.
  • Neurodegenerative disorders: Many neurodegenerative disorders are associated with dysregulation of autophagy e.g Alzheimer disease- accelerated autophagy; Huntington disease- impaired autophagy.
  • Infectious diseases: Many pathogens are degraded by autophagy e.g. mycobacteria, Shigella, HSV-1.
  • Inflammatory bowel diseases: Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis have been linked to mutations in autophagy-related genes.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ________

questions.solution:
Clinical history of hematuria, polyurea, and hypertension and gross image together suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are not associated with hepatic fibrosis. 

However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD:

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys that ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis, subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.
  • Occasional cysts have been reported in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of spontaneous excessive bruising and haemarthrosis. On investigation, he has a normal platelet count, prolonged PTT, and a normal PT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Haemophilia A. Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) following minor trauma is particularly characteristic of hemophilia.

  • Hemophilia A, the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding, is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade.
  • Hemophilia A is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait and thus affects mainly males and homozygous females.
  • About 30% of patients have no family history; their disease is caused by new mutations.
  • Hemophilia A -  clinical severity correlates well with the level of factor VIII activity.
  • Those with less than 1% of normal levels have a severe disease; those with 2% to 5% of normal levels have moderately severe disease, and those with 6% to 50% of normal levels have mild disease.
  • A tendency toward easy bruising and massive hemorrhage after trauma or operative procedures.
  • Spontaneous hemorrhages frequently occur in regions of the body that are susceptible to trauma, particularly the joints, where they are known as hemarthroses.
  • Recurrent bleeding into the joints leads to progressive deformities that can be crippling.
  • Petechiae are characteristically absent.
  • Patients with hemophilia A have a prolonged PTT and a normal PT results that point to an abnormality of the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • Factor VIII-specific assays are required for diagnosis.

questions.text: The following slides are Immunohistochemistries (IHC) done for HER 2 protein expression in patients with breast carcinoma. Among these which of the following should be subjected to fluorescent in-situ hybridisation (FISH)?

choices.text: Only "B" - To determine Gene amplification status

questions.solution:
The IHC images respectively show

  • A – 1+ (HER2 Negative)
  • B – 3+ (HER2 Positive – strong circumferential membrane staining in >10% cells)
  • C – 2+ (Equivocal – moderately strong circumferential staining in >10 % of cells)

Among these, all cases showing IHC 2+ (equivocal) should be subjected to FISH to determine gene amplification status. If the FISH results are positive then they are labelled as Her-2 positive.

Since the advent of targetted therapy for HER2 positive tumours (Trastuzumab, Lapatinib), it is important to determine HER2 status in every breast cancer patients. HER2 status is primarily determined by immunohistochemistry and/or fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)

HER2-positive tumours are

  • Tumours that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not necessary)
  • Tumours that show 2+ staining on IHC and HER2-gene amplification detected by in situ hybridization

Related Pearl: Newer molecular tests in breast cancer

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy.

These are

  • Oncotype Dx
  • Mammaprint
  • EndoPredict
  • PAM50

Is a 21-gene assay  Is a 70-gene assay

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy.
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added.

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident after which he was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth but was able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory:

Explicit/declarative memory: Memory of factual knowledge about the people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) E.g., Knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex; and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) E.g., Recalling the events occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory: It does not require being conscious or aware. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependant on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy, on examination, was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz), but an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by the Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting the Meissner's corpuscles.

 

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four types of mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

  • Meissner corpuscles
  • Merkel cells
  • Ruffini corpuscles
  • Pacinian corpuscles

 

Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz).

 

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch.

 

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibration.

 

Pacinian corpuscles:

  • They are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm in length and 1mm in diameter.
  • They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin.
  • A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance.
  • They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with a fractured femur after a road traffic accident. Complete blood count revealed a WBC count of 22,000/μl. The intern who saw the result immediately reported the finding to the resident who suggested to repeat the test after 6 hours which showed  WBC count of 7,000/μl. choices.text: Transient increased production of WBCs due to stress
Release of pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation
Increased concentration of WBCs due to sudden loss of blood

questions.solution:
The initial rise in WBC concentration is due to the release of pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation.

Majority of the mature WBCs, which is almost three times the circulating WBCs, are stored in the bone marrow, and are released into the circulation when stimulated by an increased level of cytokines. However, in conditions such as trauma, there is an increased release of the pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation, in response to stress, leading to the elevated WBC count.

However, the rise in WBC count is transient, and will return back to the normal levels within a few hours.

questions.text: In a case-control study, lung compliance of two different groups (B and C) was studied against the control group (A) and recorded as shown in the graph below. Which of the following cases, likely represents the groups B and C, respectively?

choices.text: Pulmonary emphysema and normal ageing lung
Alveolar oedema and normal ageing lung

questions.solution:
Graphs B and C correspond to increased and decreased compliance respectively. Among the given options, pulmonary emphysema is associated with increased compliance, and pulmonary fibrosis is associated with decreased compliance.

Compliance is defined as a change in lung volume per unit change in surrounding pressure. It is expressed as:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP.

The graph shown below explains the change in volume of the lung, as the intrapleural pressure increases. 

Here the compliance of B>A>C.

Compliance is increased in normal ageing lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched). 

Compliance is decreased in pulmonary fibrosis, alveolar oedema, unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea.  On auscultation, a holosystoloic murmur was heard over the left 5th intercostal space, in the mid-clavicular line. Which of the following left ventricular pressure-volume loops is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Holosystolic murmur heard over the left 5th intercostal space in mid-clavicular line is suggestive of mitral regurgitation. The pressure-volume loop represented as 'D' corresponds to mitral regurgitation.

Changes in the pressure-volume loop in mitral regurgitation:

  • At the beginning of the systole, there is no true isovolumetric contraction.
  • As the ventricle begins to contract, the blood flows back (regurgitates) into the left atrium. As a result, the afterload on the left ventricle is reduced.
  • This results in larger stroke volume, and smaller end-systolic volume.
  • There is no true isovolumetric relaxation, because, as long as the intraventricular pressure is more than the atrial pressure, the blood continues to flow back into the left atrium.
  • During diastole, the increased left atrial pressure causes increased ventricular filling, thus increasing the end-diastolic volume.

The LV pressure-volume loops shown corresponds to:

B. Mitral stenosis

questions.text: In spirometry, during forced expiration, the FEV1 is independent of which of the following?
questions.solution:
FEV1 is independent of the expiratory effort due to dynamic compression of the airways.

Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) is reduced in conditions associated with

  • Reduced elastic recoil of the lung, or
  • Increased airway resistance.

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

Dynamic compression of airways in forced expiration:

  • The forced expiratory flow is largely independent of muscular effort, as the flow is determined by the difference between alveolar and pleural pressure (transpulmonary pressure).
  • Before inspiration, the pressure in the airway is 0, while the intrapleural pressure is -5 cm H2O. Thus, a transpulmonary pressure of +5 keeps the airway open.
  • During inspiration, both alveolar and intrapleural pressure drops by 2 cm of H2O, however, in the airway, there is a pressure drop of -1 cm. Therefore, the transpulmonary pressure of +6 cm H2O keeps the airway open.
  • At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure becomes 0, while the transpulmonary pressure is +8.
  • During forced expiration, an increase in muscular effort causes an increase in the pleural pressure by 38 cm of water, which is transmitted to the alveloi. However, as the flow begins there is a pressure drop in the airways to 19cm H2O, thus causing a negative transpulmonary pressure of -11, which causes compression of the airway. 
  • Hence, during forced expiration, an increase or decrease in the muscular effort will cause an increase or decrease in compression of airways, and thus the end-expiratory flow is unaltered.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest concentration in the saliva, under resting conditions?
questions.solution:
The concentration of the bicarbonate is highest in the saliva (50 to 70 mEq/L).

Secretion of ions in saliva:

  • Salivary secretion occurs in two stages.
  • The first stage involves acini, which secrete ptyalin and/or mucin together with some ions. The composition of the ions is similar to that of the extra-cellular fluid.
  • The second stage involves the ducts. As the primary salivary secretion flows through the ducts, two active transport processes occur:
    • Na+ is actively re-absorbed and K+ is actively secreted, in exchange for Na+.
    • HCO3- is secreted by the ductal epithelium into the lumen of the salivary ducts. Some of this secretion occurs by passive exchange of bicarbonate for Cl-.
  • As a result, the Na+ and Cl- concentrations are lower than that of plasma, while K+ and HCO3- concentrations are higher than that of plasma.

Composition of ions:

  • Under resting conditions, the concentrations of Na+ and Cl- in saliva are about 15 mEq/L each, which is 1/7th to 1/10th that of the plasma concentrations.
  • K+ concentration is about 30 mEq/L, which is seven times higher than that of plasma.
  • HCO3- concentration is 50 to 70 mEq/L, which is two to three times higher than that of the plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following events occur when a normal person makes an inspiratory effort against a closed airway?
questions.solution:
Tension in the diaphragm increases, when an inspiratory effort is made against a closed airway. All other options are incorrect.

The primary inspiratory muscles, which include the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles (not internal intercostal), become active.

When the inspiratory effort is made against the closed airway, air does not enter the lungs, and all the pressures inside the thorax fall, including the pulmonary vascular pressures.

The contraction of the inspiratory muscles will cause a slight increase in the lung volume. According to Boyle’s law, the product of pressure and volume remains constant (at constant temperature). Therefore, as the volume of the lung increases, the intrathoracic pressure decreases.

The intrapleural pressure will fall (becomes more negative). If the lung volume does not change, the alveolar pressure will fall equally with the intrapleural pressure. However, if the lung volume increases, due to the action of the inspiratory muscles, then the intrapleural pressure will fall more than the alveolar pressure due to increased elastic recoil.

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo due to fluid accumulation in the corneal epithelium

The image shows a stenopaeic slit

It causes

  • Reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit.
  • No change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it.

So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding epigenetic modification:

The acetylation of histone favors active transcription
Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon involved in epigenetic gene inactivation
DNA methylation is restricted between cytosine and guanine residues connected by hydrogen bonds

questions.solution:
DNA methylation usually occurs between cytosine and guanine residues connected by phosphodiester bond(CpG) island on the same strand.

Epigenetics is defined as heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. It alters gene expression without the mutation. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. If it causes gene inactivation, it is known as Genomic imprinting.  

The epigenetic modification includes:

  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in core histones which activates and deactivates gene expression respectively. Acetylation of histone favors active transcription.
  • Methylation of histones: Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: Severe disfigurement and photosensitivity is seen in patients with Gunther's disease caused due to Uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency. It is also known as:

 Reddish discoloration of teeth, erythrodontia is seen in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia.

Hereditary coproporphyria is due to deficient coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX) and presents with colic, photosensitivity, and neurologic symptoms.

X-linked dominant protoporphyria is caused by deficient δ-aminolevulinate synthase (ALAS) and manifests as cutaneous photosensitivity.

questions.text: You are a biochemistry resident and perform the test for the reducing sugars during a lab demonstration. The outcomes of the test appear as shown in the image below. The reagent which you have used for this test contains all of the following contents except ____.
questions.solution:
The given test is Benedict's test, the Benedict's reagent used contains all the above contents except sodium hydroxide.

Benedict’s test is a test for reducing sugars. It is answered by all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulphate: Provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate: Complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate: Provides an alkaline pH

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

Clinical correlate: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of glucose in urine.

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea about the amount of sugar present in urine. Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

GGT level is rapidly decreased within a few days when the person stops taking alcohol. An increase in GGT level is generally proportional to the amount of alcohol intake.
